title: PSA: Make sure to change your passwords after an event like cloudbleed
body:
Got onto the PBE after a while without playing and found that my PBE account's summoner name had changed. And it also had a chat restriction for toxicity.

**MAKE SURE YOU CHANGE YOUR PASSWORDS, PEOPLE.**

replies.body:
Or even better:

* Don't re-use your passwords.

* Don't use the same password for multiple services.

One of the reasons why database breaches like cloudbleed are so dangerous, is because people are surprisingly dumb when it comes to their IT security, and use the samepassword for facebook, gmail, league, wow, instagram, snapchat, whatsapp,...and that new webservice which just happens to get hacked.

Guess what the first thing someone who gets his hands on one of the lists does after hashbreaking passwords?
HE TRIES THE EMAIL-PW COMBINATION ON EVERY OTHER WEBSERVICE.

And that isn't done by hand folks.
There are scripts that do that.
Automatically.
Millions of passwords in a few minutes.

So: Start using different passwords, for different services!!

And if you have trouble remembering passwords:

What would you personally recommend to us "noobs?"

First of all, you are not "noobs".

I understand that most people don't have a lot of knowledge in cyber security.
And that's fine.
I don't expect my physician to know how to fix my car, and I don't expect my companies human ressource manager to be able to pick a good side of beef for me at the butchers shop.

I think I made it abudantly clear what options people have to improve their online security.

Either memorize a multitude of strong passwords to give unique ones to all online services used (which is something that some people are actually able to do, same as some people can memorize and recall 20 or 30 telephone numbers at will without breaking a sweat)...

...or get, and learn how to use, a good password manager.

One can use **open source software**, which is usually free (as in: doesn't cost money) but most importantly, because the community has control over the code and independent parties can check it for anything fishy going on.

But open source comes with its own caveats, its usually not as user friendly and lacks the interface polishing that you find in **commercial software**. Also, sometimes the developer quits, and no one picks up after him, meaning if one is not careful, one could run into using an outdated (aka. insecure) piece of software.

And then there is the third option, which is what I did:** I wrote my own password manager**. However, I don't recommend doing that, unless you actually know quite a bit about programming and kryptography.

So there are the options.
As to recommending specific programs, that is not a decision I can or want to make for others.
You have internet access, and you are an independently thinking human being.
That's all the tools you require to make your own choices.

But kudos for giving thought to the matter at all.
Most people don't.

I use 1password, it's really easy to use and will help generate unique complex passwords for every account. Takes a bit to set up and change passwords on your old accounts, but it's worth it.

It is not a bad solution, but I personally do not like proprietary password managers, for a very simple reason:

They are not open source.

I want to believe that this is not a problem. I truly do.
I would love to live in a world where that could never be a problem.
But: If the code I entrust the security of my personal informations to, is written by a company, without me having access to that code to inspect it....

...then at least for me, that is a no-go.

I just smash the keyboard for something like this:

tg4f311jf320asd

Then I'll throw in some special characters !@#$%^& wherever.

Then I actually remember that.

I'll write it down on a sticky by the computer (at home obviously).

After a couple weeks of inputting it, it becomes second nature :)

>tg4f311jf320asd

The password you "randomly" generated is not as random as you may think.
Lets have a look at it:

A) It contains only lower case letters and numbers, something that is common with "keyboardsmash" passwords

B) It contains patterns of key combinations, generated by physical proximity of keys on the keyboard and the way human hands work:

* **tgf**...next to, or near each other, top down oriented (smash moves usually go top to bottom)

* **4312** as most of the interspersed numbers ... the leftmost numbers on the board.

* **asd **... one of the most common combinations of "random" keyboard smashing, 3 bottons next to each other, ordered left-to-right

* **jf** ... this will be in almost every "random smash" password written on an european/uk/us keyboard, because those are the two "rest-position" buttons (ever noticed the little heightened "bumps" on them? that's why they are there ;D)

All those are patterns, and patterns are where passwords become interesting to crackers, because they provide a way in. Its hard to brute force by trying every combination of 15 characters, even if they are only numbers and lowercase letters. But when one can reasonably predict that something like "asd" or "jf" is in there, with a possibility for slight variations, then the number of passwords that have to be tried, the "pool" suddenly becomes smaller by several orders of magnitude.

The special characters used make it a lot stronger, yes, but look at which ones you are using: The most common ones, which are used in most forms of writing. The only 3 your list is missing, are . ? and -

Would it surprise you to hear, that there are wordlists, with hundreds of thousands of entries, of "randomsmash" passwords of variable length available to security experts? Its pretty simple to do primitive statistics on this data, and the result is: The "randomness" of random smashing is shockingly low.

If I remember correctly (and I am not sure that I do), excels encryption method does some truncating in the key generation, so there are "only" around 2^40 possible **keys** that can be calculated by using data available openly in the document.

Keys and Password are different things ... the password is used to generate the key, which is then used to encrypt/decrypt the data.

Its very hard to brute force the password of an encrypted excel file (if it is as strong PW).
But not necessary. One can instead attack the key itself.

And that can be done pretty quickly. A modern CPU would have little trouble to calculate around 10^6 keys / sec and trying them, which means around 2 weeks to cover the keyspace. With a little code optimization and forking on a multicore processor, that goes down to a few days. With a strong GPU-server, it could be done in a few hours.

Not to mention that encrypted excel brings us right back to one of the problems I avoid like the plague: Security entrusted to proprietary software ^^

The best way to keep a password safe is inside your head. Which can be a little confusing for some of the lengths/many websites but way less chance.

pretty interesting, what would make a strong password then? Some people I know use a combination of favorite sports players names and numbers, like Tony9Romo or Michael23Jordan. Or create a random word with vowel-consonant-vowel pattern, like gomopur. Others will use their street address 12345FakeSt.

>a combination of favorite sports players names and numbers

Not a good idea.
Lists of celebrity names exist as well, precisely because passwords using these names are so common. Some of the better lists are even updated regularly and automatically based on popularity and how much celebrities are mentioned on social media like twitter .D

>Others will use their street address 12345FakeSt.

Street addresses are not much stronger.

Yes, there are a lot of streets, but actually not a lot of street names. How many "Main St." are there? How many "Park Av."?
And addresses **also have patterns.** For example, most addresses in the US follow this scheme:

[Nr.] [Street Name]
[Town], [State] [Zip-Code]

That's already a lot of information about a password given away for free.

Also, if ones password is stolen and broken, that's bad enough. There really is no reason to add insult to injury by also having ones reallife address revealed  by that.

>what would make a strong password then?

That depends what you define as strong.
A 500 digit alphanumeric password would be almost unbreakable, but also impossible to remember, let alone type.


Some very good passwords are actually easy to remember pass-phrases, with some simple rules thrown in to increase entropy.

A few words in english, one word in a foreign language, and two different deliminators between the words is oftentimes a lot more entropy (a measurement for how many tries it would take on average to break a password) than an overly complicated word-to-leetspeak-with-some-special-characters or other "clever scheme" which may look like its secure, but is actually just hard to remember, while being very vulnerable to attacks.
